spectacles, and then again resuming his walk, muttering indistinct words, shrugging his shoulders and gesticulating. 
"England is done for," said he, scowling and pointing his finger at someone unseen. "Mr. Pitt, as a traitor to the nation and to the rights of man, is sentenced to . . ." But before Pierre who at that moment imagined himself to be Napoleon in person and to have just effected the dangerous crossing of the Straits of Dover and captured London could pronounce Pitt's sentence, he
